# Decouple retro framework from app via import maps

## Context
App files (`src/app/*.ts`) currently import retro via relative path (`../retro/index.js`). This couples them and prevents building retro separately. We'll use browser-native import maps so app code imports from the bare specifier `'retro'`, and split the build into two independent tsconfigs.

## Changes

### 1. Create `tsconfig.base.json` (shared compiler options)
Replace current `tsconfig.json` with a base config containing shared options:
- `target`, `module`, `moduleResolution`, `strict`, `esModuleInterop`, `declaration`, `sourceMap`
- No `include`, `outDir`, or `rootDir`

### 2. Create `src/retro/tsconfig.json`
- Extends `../../tsconfig.base.json`
- `rootDir: .`, `outDir: ../../dist/retro`, `include: ["."]`

### 3. Create `src/app/tsconfig.json`
- Extends `../../tsconfig.base.json`
- `rootDir: .`, `outDir: ../../dist/app`, `include: ["."]`
- `paths: { "retro": ["../retro/index.ts"] }`  r...

# Deploy Kanban demo to GitHub Pages

## Context
The app is served from `public/` with built JS in `dist/`. For GitHub Pages at `godmar.github.io/retro`, we need both under one root. The `index.html` references `../dist/` (sibling relationship), which needs to become `./dist/` when everything is flattened into a single site directory.

## Plan

### Create `.github/workflows/deploy.yml`
A single workflow file that:
1. Triggers on push to `master`
2. Sets up Node, installs deps, runs `npm run build`
3. Assembles `_site/` directory:
   - Copy `public/*`  `_site/`
   - Copy `dist/`  `_site/dist/`
   - Fix `../dist/`  `./dist/` in `_site/index.html` (two occurrences: import map and script src)
4. Uses `actions/upload-pages-artifact` + `actions/deploy-pages` to publish

Uses the "GitHub Actions" pages source (not branch-based), so no `gh-pages` branch is needed.

## Files
- `.github/workflows/deploy.yml` (new)

Design a lightweight client-side SPA framework called "retro" with these constraints:

...

Design a lightweight client-side SPA framework called "retro" with these constraints:

  1. No build process other than tsc (TypeScript compiler) - no bundlers, no webpack, no vite
  2. Client-side only (SPA), no SSR
  3. Uses standard HTML/DOM API directly - no virtual DOM
  4. Uses HTML <template> elements for component templates
  5. Written in TypeScript, client code also in TypeScript
  6. Deployment: a static .html file that loads compiled JS via ES modules

The framework needs to support building a Kanban board demo app with localStorage persistence.

Design the architecture covering:

Framework Core (src/retro/):

  • Component system: How components are defined, how they use <template> elements, lifecycle hooks
  • Reactivity: How state changes trigger DOM updates (consider a simple reactive state/signal pattern)
  • Routing: Simple hash-based router for SPA navigation
  • Template binding: How templates bind to component state (data binding, event handling, list rendering)
  • How <template> elements work with cloning and dynamic content insertion

Key Design Decisions:

  • Since no bundler: use ES module imports with .js extensions in import paths (tsc compiles .ts to .js but doesn't rewrite import paths)
  • Templates defined in HTML <template> tags in the main index.html, referenced by id
  • Components as TypeScript classes that extend a base Component class
  • Reactive state using a simple signal/observable pattern that triggers targeted DOM updates
  • Event delegation or direct event binding on template-cloned elements

Demo App (src/app/):

  • Kanban board with columns (e.g., To Do, In Progress, Done)
  • Cards with title and description
  • Drag-and-drop between columns
  • Add/edit/delete cards
  • localStorage persistence

Project Structure:

  • src/retro/ - framework source (TypeScript)
  • src/app/ - demo app source (TypeScript)
  • public/index.html - the static HTML file with templates
  • tsconfig.json - configured for ES modules output

Build:

  • tsc compiles src/**/*.ts to dist/**/*.js
  • public/index.html references dist/app/main.js as module entry point

Provide a detailed file-by-file plan with the key APIs and classes for each file. Keep the framework minimal but functional enough for the Kanban demo.

# Retro Framework + Kanban Demo Plan

## Context

Create "retro"  a minimal client-side SPA framework that embraces web standards: HTML `<template>`, native DOM API, ES modules, and TypeScript. No bundler, no virtual DOM, no SSR. Then demonstrate it with a Kanban board app using localStorage.

## Project Structure

```
retro/
 public/
    index.html          # Static HTML with <template> elements, loads ES module entry
 src/
    retro/
       component.ts    # Base Component class
       router.ts       # Hash-based SPA router
       index.ts        # Re-exports framework API
    app/
        main.ts          # App entry point, registers routes/components
        store.ts         # Kanban data model + localStorage persistence
        board.ts         # Board component (columns + cards)
        card-editor.ts   # Card create/edit dialog component
 tsconfig.json
 package.json             # (exists already)
```

## Build & Serve

- **tsconfig.json**: `target: ES2022`, `module: ES2022`, `outDir: dist`, `rootDir: src`, `strict: true`
- **Build script**: `"build": "tsc"` in package.json
- **Output**: `tsc` compiles `src/**/*.ts`  `dist/**/*.js`
- **index.html** loads `<script type="module" src="dist/app/main.js">`
- **Serve**: any static file server (e.g., `npx http-server .` or `python3 -m http.server`)

## Framework Design

### 1. `src/retro/component.ts`  Base Component Class

```typescript
abstract class Component {
  protected root: HTMLElement;

  constructor(container: HTMLElement, templateId: string) {
    // Clone <template id="templateId"> and append to container
  }

  // Subclasses override to bind events after template is cloned
  abstract mount(): void;

  // Triggers a re-render: clears container, re-clones template, re-mounts
  protected setState(updater: () => void): void {
    updater();
    this.render();
  }

  // Clears root, clones template, calls mount()
  protected render(): void { ... }

  // Helper: query within this component's root
  protected query<T extends HTMLElement>(selector: string): T { ... }
  protected queryAll<T extends HTMLElement>(selector: string): T[] { ... }

  // Cleanup hook
  destroy(): void { ... }
}
```

**Key behavior:**
- Templates are `<template>` elements defined in `index.html` with unique `id` attributes
- `render()` clones the template, appends it to the container, then calls `mount()`
- `mount()` is where subclasses query DOM nodes, set text content, add event listeners
- `setState()` calls the updater function, then re-renders (full component re-render  simple and predictable)
- Components manage a root element; re-render replaces its children

### 2. `src/retro/router.ts`  Hash Router

```typescript
class Router {
  private routes: Map<string, (params: Record<string, string>) => void>;

  addRoute(pattern: string, handler: (params) => void): void;
  navigate(hash: string): void;
  start(): void;  // Listen to hashchange, trigger initial route
}
```

- Pattern matching: simple string routes like `#/` and `#/board/:id`
- On route match, handler is called  typically mounts a component into a container element

### 3. `src/retro/index.ts`  Public API

Re-exports `Component` and `Router`.

## Kanban Demo App

### Data Model (`src/app/store.ts`)

```typescript
interface Card {
  id: string;
  title: string;
  description: string;
  columnId: string;
}

interface Column {
  id: string;
  title: string;
}

interface BoardState {
  columns: Column[];
  cards: Card[];
}

class Store {
  private state: BoardState;

  constructor()           // Load from localStorage or use defaults
  save(): void            // Persist to localStorage
  getColumns(): Column[]
  getCards(columnId: string): Card[]
  addCard(columnId: string, title: string, description: string): Card
  updateCard(id: string, updates: Partial<Card>): void
  deleteCard(id: string): void
  moveCard(cardId: string, targetColumnId: string): void
}
```

Default columns: "To Do", "In Progress", "Done".

### Board Component (`src/app/board.ts`)

- Uses template `#board-template` for overall layout
- Dynamically creates column elements, each containing its cards
- Each card is cloned from `#card-template`
- **Drag & drop**: HTML5 DnD API
  - Cards have `draggable="true"`, `dragstart` sets card ID in dataTransfer
  - Columns listen for `dragover` (prevent default) and `drop` (move card via store)
- Buttons to add new cards per column, delete cards

### Card Editor (`src/app/card-editor.ts`)

- Uses template `#card-editor-template`  a modal/dialog form
- Fields: title (input), description (textarea)
- Used for both creating and editing cards
- On submit: calls store.addCard() or store.updateCard(), then re-renders board

### Entry Point (`src/app/main.ts`)

```typescript
const store = new Store();
const router = new Router();
const appRoot = document.getElementById('app')!;

router.addRoute('#/', () => {
  new BoardComponent(appRoot, store);
});

router.start();
```

### Templates in `public/index.html`

```html
<!-- Board layout with columns container -->
<template id="board-template">...</template>

<!-- Single column with title and card list -->
<template id="column-template">...</template>

<!-- Single card with title, description, drag handle -->
<template id="card-template">...</template>

<!-- Modal form for card creation/editing -->
<template id="card-editor-template">...</template>
```

The HTML file also includes basic CSS (inline `<style>` or linked CSS file) for the Kanban layout: flexbox columns, card styling, drag-over visual feedback.

## Implementation Order

1. **tsconfig.json**  configure TypeScript compilation
2. **src/retro/component.ts**  base Component class with template cloning, setState, render
3. **src/retro/router.ts**  hash-based router
4. **src/retro/index.ts**  re-exports
5. **src/app/store.ts**  data model + localStorage
6. **src/app/board.ts**  board + column + card rendering with DnD
7. **src/app/card-editor.ts**  card create/edit dialog
8. **src/app/main.ts**  entry point, wiring
9. **public/index.html**  templates, styles, script tag
10. **Update package.json**  add build script
11. **Build & test**  `npm run build`, serve, verify in browser

## Verification

1. Run `npm run build`  should compile with no errors
2. Serve with `npx http-server . -p 8080` (or similar)
3. Open browser to `http://localhost:8080/public/index.html`
4. Verify: 3 columns displayed, can add cards, can edit/delete cards
5. Verify: drag cards between columns, drop updates column assignment
6. Verify: refresh page  cards persist via localStorage
7. Verify: clear localStorage  returns to empty default state

  • Router hash-based routing with simple pattern matching
  • Manual setState model as you chose call updater, then re-render

  • Store Kanban data (columns + cards) with localStorage persistence

Retro Framework + Kanban Demo Plan

Context

Create "retro" a minimal client-side SPA framework that embraces web standards: HTML <template>, native DOM API, ES modules, and TypeScript. No bundler, no virtual DOM, no SSR. Then demonstrate it with a Kanban board app using localStorage.

Project Structure

retro/
 public/
    index.html          # Static HTML with <template> elements, loads ES module entry
 src/
    retro/
       component.ts    # Base Component class
       router.ts       # Hash-based SPA router
       index.ts        # Re-exports framework API
    app/
        main.ts          # App entry point, registers routes/components
        store.ts         # Kanban data model + localStorage persistence
        board.ts         # Board component (columns + cards)
        card-editor.ts   # Card create/edit dialog component
 tsconfig.json
 package.json             # (exists already)

Build & Serve

  • tsconfig.json: target: ES2022, module: ES2022, outDir: dist, rootDir: src, strict: true
  • Build script: "build": "tsc" in package.json
  • Output: tsc compiles src/**/*.ts dist/**/*.js
  • index.html loads <script type="module" src="dist/app/main.js">
  • Serve: any static file server (e.g., npx http-server . or python3 -m http.server)

Framework Design

1. src/retro/component.ts Base Component Class

abstract class Component {
  protected root: HTMLElement;

  constructor(container: HTMLElement, templateId: string) {
    // Clone <template id="templateId"> and append to container
  }

  // Subclasses override to bind events after template is cloned
  abstract mount(): void;

  // Triggers a re-render: clears container, re-clones template, re-mounts
  protected setState(updater: () => void): void {
    updater();
    this.render();
  }

  // Clears root, clones template, calls mount()
  protected render(): void { ... }

  // Helper: query within this component's root
  protected query<T extends HTMLElement>(selector: string): T { ... }
  protected queryAll<T extends HTMLElement>(selector: string): T[] { ... }

  // Cleanup hook
  destroy(): void { ... }
}

Key behavior:

  • Templates are <template> elements defined in index.html with unique id attributes
  • render() clones the template, appends it to the container, then calls mount()
  • mount() is where subclasses query DOM nodes, set text content, add event listeners
  • setState() calls the updater function, then re-renders (full component re-render simple and predictable)
  • Components manage a root element; re-render replaces its children

2. src/retro/router.ts Hash Router

class Router {
  private routes: Map<string, (params: Record<string, string>) => void>;

  addRoute(pattern: string, handler: (params) => void): void;
  navigate(hash: string): void;
  start(): void;  // Listen to hashchange, trigger initial route
}

# Retro Framework + Kanban Demo Plan

## Context

Create "retro"  a minimal client-side SPA framework that embraces web standards: HTML `<template>`, native DOM API, ES modules, and TypeScript. No bundler, no virtual DOM, no SSR. Then demonstrate it with a Kanban board app using localStorage.

## Project Structure

```
retro/
 public/
    index.html          # Static HTML with <template> elements, loads ES module entry
 src/
    retro/
       component.ts    # Base Component class
       router.ts       # Hash-based SPA router
       index.ts        # Re-exports framework API
    app/
        main.ts          # App entry point, registers routes/components
        store.ts         # Kanban data model + localStorage persistence
        board.ts         # Board component (columns + cards)
        card-editor.ts   # Card create/edit dialog component
 tsconfig.json
 package.json             # (exists already)
```

## Build & Serve

- **tsconfig.json**: `target: ES2022`, `module: ES2022`, `outDir: dist`, `rootDir: src`, `strict: true`
- **Build script**: `"build": "tsc"` in package.json
- **Output**: `tsc` compiles `src/**/*.ts`  `dist/**/*.js`
- **index.html** loads `<script type="module" src="dist/app/main.js">`
- **Serve**: any static file server (e.g., `npx http-server .` or `python3 -m http.server`)

## Framework Design

### 1. `src/retro/component.ts`  Base Component Class

```typescript
abstract class Component {
  protected root: HTMLElement;

  constructor(container: HTMLElement, templateId: string) {
    // Clone <template id="templateId"> and append to container
  }

  // Subclasses override to bind events after template is cloned
  abstract mount(): void;

  // Triggers a re-render: clears container, re-clones template, re-mounts
  protected setState(updater: () => void): void {
    updater();
    this.render();
  }

  // Clears root, clones template, calls mount()
  protected render(): void { ... }

  // Helper: query within this component's root
  protected query<T extends HTMLElement>(selector: string): T { ... }
  protected queryAll<T extends HTMLElement>(selector: string): T[] { ... }

  // Cleanup hook
  destroy(): void { ... }
}
```

**Key behavior:**
- Templates are `<template>` elements defined in `index.html` with unique `id` attributes
- `render()` clones the template, appends it to the container, then calls `mount()`
- `mount()` is where subclasses query DOM nodes, set text content, add event listeners
- `setState()` calls the updater function, then re-renders (full component re-render  simple and predictable)
- Components manage a root element; re-render replaces its children

### 2. `src/retro/router.ts`  Hash Router

```typescript
class Router {
  private routes: Map<string, (params: Record<string, string>) => void>;

  addRoute(pattern: string, handler: (params) => void): void;
  navigate(hash: string): void;
  start(): void;  // Listen to hashchange, trigger initial route
}
```

- Pattern matching: simple string routes like `#/` and `#/board/:id`
- On route match, handler is called  typically mounts a component into a container element

### 3. `src/retro/index.ts`  Public API

Re-exports `Component` and `Router`.

export abstract class Component {
  protected root: HTMLElement;
  private templateId: string;

  constructor(container: HTMLElement, templateId: string) {
    this.root = container;
    this.templateId = templateId;
    this.render();
  }

  abstract mount(): void;

  protected setState(updater: () => void): void {
    updater();
    this.render();
  }

  protected render(): void {
    this.root.innerHTML = '';
    const template = document.getElementById(this.templateId) as HTMLTemplateElement | null;
    if (!template) {
      throw new Error(`Template #${this.templateId} not found`);
    }
    const clone = template.content.cloneNode(true) as DocumentFragment;
    this.root.appendChild(clone);
    this.mount();
  }

  protected query<T extends HTMLElement>(selector: string): T {
    const el = this.root.querySelector<T>(selector);
    if (!el) {
      throw new Error(`Element not found: ${selector}`);
    }
    return el;
  }

  protected queryAll<T extends HTMLElement>(selector: string): T[] {
    return Array.from(this.root.querySelectorAll<T>(selector));
  }

  destroy(): void {
    this.root.innerHTML = '';
  }
}

interface Route {

type RouteHandler = (params: Record<string, string>) => void;

interface Route {
  pattern: string;
  parts: string[];
  handler: RouteHandler;
}

export class Router {
  private routes: Route[] = [];

  addRoute(pattern: string, handler: RouteHandler): void {
    const parts = pattern.replace(/^#/, '').split('/');
    this.routes.push({ pattern, parts, handler });
  }

  navigate(hash: string): void {
    window.location.hash = hash;
  }

  start(): void {
    window.addEventListener('hashchange', () => this.resolve());
    this.resolve();
  }

  private resolve(): void {
    const hash = window.location.hash || '#/';
    const path = hash.replace(/^#/, '');
    const segments = path.split('/');

    for (const route of this.routes) {
      const params = this.match(route.parts, segments);
      if (params !== null) {
        route.handler(params);
        return;
      }
    }
  }

  private match(
    routeParts: string[],
    pathParts: string[]
  ): Record<string, string> | null {
    if (routeParts.length !== pathParts.length) return null;

    const params: Record<string, string> = {};
    for (let i = 0; i < routeParts.length; i++) {
      if (routeParts[i].startsWith(':')) {
        params[routeParts[i].slice(1)] = pathParts[i];
      } else if (routeParts[i] !== pathParts[i]) {
        return null;
      }
    }
    return params;
  }
}

export interface Card {
  id: string;
  title: string;
  description: string;
  columnId: string;
}

export interface Column {
  id: string;
  title: string;
}

export interface BoardState {
  columns: Column[];
  cards: Card[];
}

const STORAGE_KEY = 'retro-kanban';

const DEFAULT_COLUMNS: Column[] = [
  { id: 'todo', title: 'To Do' },
  { id: 'in-progress', title: 'In Progress' },
  { id: 'done', title: 'Done' },
];

export class Store {
  private state: BoardState;

  constructor() {
    const saved = localStorage.getItem(STORAGE_KEY);
    if (saved) {
      this.state = JSON.parse(saved);
    } else {
      this.state = { columns: DEFAULT_COLUMNS, cards: [] };
    }
  }

  save(): void {
    localStorage.setItem(STORAGE_KEY, JSON.stringify(this.state));
  }

  getColumns(): Column[] {
    return this.state.columns;
  }

  getCards(columnId: string): Card[] {
    return this.state.cards.filter((c) => c.columnId === columnId);
  }

  addCard(columnId: string, title: string, description: string): Card {
    const card: Card = {
      id: crypto.randomUUID(),
      title,
      description,
      columnId,
    };
    this.state.cards.push(card);
    this.save();
    return card;
  }

  updateCard(id: string, updates: Partial<Card>): void {
    const card = this.state.cards.find((c) => c.id === id);
    if (card) {
      Object.assign(card, updates);
      this.save();
    }
  }

  deleteCard(id: string): void {
    this.state.cards = this.state.cards.filter((c) => c.id !== id);
    this.save();
  }

  moveCard(cardId: string, targetColumnId: string): void {
    this.updateCard(cardId, { columnId: targetColumnId });
  }

  getCard(id: string): Card | undefined {
    return this.state.cards.find((c) => c.id === id);
  }
}

export class CardEditor extends Component {
  private onClose: () => void;

import { Component } from '../retro/index.js';
import { Store } from './store.js';

export class CardEditor extends Component {
  private onClose: () => void;
  private store: Store;
  private editingCardId: string | null;
  private columnId: string;

  constructor(
    container: HTMLElement,
    store: Store,
    columnId: string,
    editingCardId: string | null,
    onClose: () => void
  ) {
    // Set fields before super() calls render() -> mount()
    // TypeScript strict mode requires definite assignment, so we use
    // Object.assign to set fields before the super call.
    const self = Object.create(CardEditor.prototype) as CardEditor;
    Object.assign(self, { store, columnId, editingCardId, onClose });
    // Now call Component constructor via apply
    Component.call(self, container, 'card-editor-template');
    return self;
  }

  mount(): void {
    const form = this.query<HTMLFormElement>('.card-editor-form');
    const titleInput = this.query<HTMLInputElement>('.card-title-input');
    const descInput = this.query<HTMLTextAreaElement>('.card-desc-input');
    const heading = this.query<HTMLElement>('.card-editor-heading');
    const cancelBtn = this.query<HTMLButtonElement>('.card-editor-cancel');

    if (this.editingCardId) {
      const card = this.store.getCard(this.editingCardId);
      if (card) {
        titleInput.value = card.title;
        descInput.value = card.description;
        heading.textContent = 'Edit Card';
      }
    } else {
      heading.textContent = 'New Card';
    }

    form.addEventListener('submit', (e) => {
      e.preventDefault();
      const title = titleInput.value.trim();
      if (!title) return;
      const description = descInput.value.trim();

      if (this.editingCardId) {
        this.store.updateCard(this.editingCardId, { title, description });
      } else {
        this.store.addCard(this.columnId, title, description);
      }
      this.onClose();
    });

    cancelBtn.addEventListener('click', () => {
      this.onClose();
    });

    // Close on backdrop click
    const overlay = this.query<HTMLElement>('.card-editor-overlay');
    overlay.addEventListener('click', (e) => {
      if (e.target === overlay) {
        this.onClose();
      }
    });
  }
}

The CardEditor constructor is problematic - I'm trying to set fields before super() which TypeScript won't allow. Let me rethink this. The issue is that Component's constructor calls render() which calls mount(), and mount() needs the fields to be set.


A cleaner approach: don't call render in Component's constructor. Instead, have a separate init() method, or pass the fields differently. But the plan says the constructor clones the template and appends...


Actually, let me just restructure CardEditor to not need the fields before super(). I can use a different pattern - initialize with a separate method, or use a factory pattern.


Better approach: make Component's constructor NOT call render(), and instead require subclasses to call this.render() after setting their fields. Or, make mount() get called lazily.


The simplest fix is to decouple rendering from the constructor entirely - Component stores the arguments without rendering, then subclasses explicitly call render() after their fields are initialized. This two-phase approach avoids the ordering problem while keeping the template cloning logic intact.

export abstract class Component {
  protected root: HTMLElement;
  private templateId: string;

  constructor(container: HTMLElement, templateId: string) {

export abstract class Component {
  protected root: HTMLElement;
  private templateId: string;

  constructor(container: HTMLElement, templateId: string) {
    this.root = container;
    this.templateId = templateId;
  }

  abstract mount(): void;

  protected setState(updater: () => void): void {
    updater();
    this.render();
  }

  protected render(): void {
    this.root.innerHTML = '';
    const template = document.getElementById(this.templateId) as HTMLTemplateElement | null;
    if (!template) {
      throw new Error(`Template #${this.templateId} not found`);
    }
    const clone = template.content.cloneNode(true) as DocumentFragment;
    this.root.appendChild(clone);
    this.mount();
  }

  protected query<T extends HTMLElement>(selector: string): T {
    const el = this.root.querySelector<T>(selector);
    if (!el) {
      throw new Error(`Element not found: ${selector}`);
    }
    return el;
  }

  protected queryAll<T extends HTMLElement>(selector: string): T[] {
    return Array.from(this.root.querySelectorAll<T>(selector));
  }

  destroy(): void {
    this.root.innerHTML = '';
  }
}

    this.editingCardId = editingCardId;
    this.onClose = onClose;

    const descInput = this.query<HTMLTextAreaElement>('.card-desc-input');

    if (this.editingCardId) {

      if (card) {
        titleInput.value = card.title;
        descInput.value = card.description;
        heading.textContent = 'Edit Card';
      }
    } else {
      heading.textContent = 'New Card';
    }

    form.addEventListener('submit', (e) => {
      e.preventDefault();
      const title = titleInput.value.trim();
      if (!title) return;
      const description = descInput.value.trim();

      if (e.target === overlay) {

export class BoardComponent extends Component {

import { Component } from '../retro/index.js';
import { Store } from './store.js';
import { CardEditor } from './card-editor.js';

export class BoardComponent extends Component {
  private store: Store;
  private editorContainer: HTMLElement | null = null;

  constructor(container: HTMLElement, store: Store) {
    super(container, 'board-template');
    this.store = store;
    this.render();
  }

  mount(): void {
    const columnsContainer = this.query<HTMLElement>('.board-columns');

    for (const column of this.store.getColumns()) {
      const colTemplate = document.getElementById('column-template') as HTMLTemplateElement;
      const colClone = colTemplate.content.cloneNode(true) as DocumentFragment;
      const colEl = colClone.firstElementChild as HTMLElement;

      colEl.querySelector('.column-title')!.textContent = column.title;
      colEl.dataset.columnId = column.id;

      // Drag and drop on column
      colEl.addEventListener('dragover', (e) => {
        e.preventDefault();
        colEl.classList.add('drag-over');
      });

      colEl.addEventListener('dragleave', () => {
        colEl.classList.remove('drag-over');
      });

      colEl.addEventListener('drop', (e) => {
        e.preventDefault();
        colEl.classList.remove('drag-over');
        const cardId = e.dataTransfer?.getData('text/plain');
        if (cardId) {
          this.store.moveCard(cardId, column.id);
          this.render();
        }
      });

      // Render cards in this column
      const cardList = colEl.querySelector('.card-list') as HTMLElement;
      const cards = this.store.getCards(column.id);

      for (const card of cards) {
        const cardTemplate = document.getElementById('card-template') as HTMLTemplateElement;
        const cardClone = cardTemplate.content.cloneNode(true) as DocumentFragment;
        const cardEl = cardClone.firstElementChild as HTMLElement;

        cardEl.querySelector('.card-title')!.textContent = card.title;
        const descEl = cardEl.querySelector('.card-description') as HTMLElement;
        if (descEl) {
          descEl.textContent = card.description;
        }
        cardEl.dataset.cardId = card.id;
        cardEl.setAttribute('draggable', 'true');

        cardEl.addEventListener('dragstart', (e) => {
          e.dataTransfer?.setData('text/plain', card.id);
        });

        // Edit button
        const editBtn = cardEl.querySelector('.card-edit-btn') as HTMLButtonElement;
        editBtn.addEventListener('click', () => {
          this.openEditor(column.id, card.id);
        });

        // Delete button
        const deleteBtn = cardEl.querySelector('.card-delete-btn') as HTMLButtonElement;
        deleteBtn.addEventListener('click', () => {
          this.store.deleteCard(card.id);
          this.render();
        });

        cardList.appendChild(cardEl);
      }

      // Add card button
      const addBtn = colEl.querySelector('.column-add-btn') as HTMLButtonElement;
      addBtn.addEventListener('click', () => {
        this.openEditor(column.id, null);
      });

      columnsContainer.appendChild(colEl);
    }
  }

  private openEditor(columnId: string, cardId: string | null): void {
    // Create a container for the editor overlay
    this.editorContainer = document.createElement('div');
    document.body.appendChild(this.editorContainer);

    new CardEditor(this.editorContainer, this.store, columnId, cardId, () => {
      this.closeEditor();
      this.render();
    });
  }

  private closeEditor(): void {
    if (this.editorContainer) {
      this.editorContainer.remove();
      this.editorContainer = null;
    }
  }
}

All done. Here's what was created:


Framework (src/retro/)


    

  • component.ts  Base Component class with template cloning, setState() for re-rendering, and DOM query helpers
    • 

  • router.ts  Hash-based SPA router with :param pattern matching
    • 

  • index.ts  Re-exports
    • 



Kanban App (src/app/)


    

  • store.ts  Store class with BoardState (columns + cards), localStorage persistence, CRUD operations
    • 

  • board.ts  BoardComponent rendering 3 columns with cards, HTML5 drag-and-drop between columns
    • 

  • card-editor.ts  Modal dialog for creating/editing cards
    • 

  • main.ts  Entry point wiring store, router, and board component
    • 



Other files


    

  • public/index.html  HTML with <template> elements, inline CSS (Trello-like styling), loads the ES module entry
    • 

  • tsconfig.json  ES2022 target/module, strict mode, src  dist
    • 

  • package.json  Added "build": "tsc" script
    • 



The build compiles cleanly. To test: serve with npx http-server . -p 8080 and open http://localhost:8080/public/index.html.

# Retro Kanban

A Kanban board single-page application built with **retro**, a minimal client-side SPA framework that embraces web standards.

## Features

- Three-column Kanban board (To Do, In Progress, Done)
- Create, edit, and delete cards
- Drag and drop cards between columns (HTML5 DnD API)
- Persistent storage via localStorage

## Tech Stack

- **retro** framework  HTML `<template>`, native DOM API, ES modules
- TypeScript (ESNext target, no bundler)
- No virtual DOM, no SSR, no build-time dependencies beyond `tsc`

## Getting Started

### Prerequisites

- Node.js (for TypeScript compiler)
- A static file server

### Build

```bash
npm install
npm run build
```

This compiles `src/**/*.ts` to `dist/**/*.js`.

### Serve

Serve the project root with any static file server and open `public/index.html`:

```bash
npx http-server . -p 8080
# Open http://localhost:8080/public/index.html
```

## Project Structure

```
retro/
 public/
    index.html       # HTML with <template> elements, loads app entry
    style.css        # Application styles
 src/
    retro/           # Framework
       component.ts # Base Component class
       router.ts    # Hash-based SPA router
       index.ts     # Public API re-exports
    app/             # Kanban demo app
        main.ts      # Entry point
        store.ts     # Data model + localStorage persistence
        board.ts     # Board component (columns + cards + DnD)
        card-editor.ts # Card create/edit dialog
 tsconfig.json
 package.json
```

## Documentation

See [docs/retro-framework.md](docs/retro-framework.md) for retro framework documentation.

# retro Framework Documentation

retro is a minimal client-side SPA framework built on web standards: HTML `<template>` elements, the native DOM API, and ES modules. It provides two core abstractions  `Component` and `Router`  and nothing else.

## Design Philosophy

- **No virtual DOM.** Components clone HTML `<template>` elements and manipulate the real DOM directly.
- **No bundler.** TypeScript compiles to ES modules that the browser loads natively.
- **No magic.** State management is explicit. Re-rendering is a full replace of the component's DOM subtree.
- **Templates in HTML.** UI structure lives in `<template>` tags in your HTML file, not in JavaScript strings or JSX.

## API Reference

### `Component`

Abstract base class for all UI components.

```typescript
import { Component } from './retro/index.js';
```

#### Constructor

```typescript
constructor(container: HTMLElement, templateId: string)
```

- `container`  the DOM element this component renders into
- `templateId`  the `id` attribute of a `<template>` element in the HTML

The constructor stores these references but does **not** render automatically. Subclasses must call `this.render()` after setting up their own fields.

#### Abstract Method: `mount()`

```typescript
abstract mount(): void;
```

Called by `render()` after the template has been cloned and appended to the container. This is where subclasses should:

- Query DOM nodes using `this.query()` / `this.queryAll()`
- Set text content, attributes, and values
- Attach event listeners
- Create child components

#### `render()`

```typescript
protected render(): void
```

Clears the container's innerHTML, clones the template, appends it, and calls `mount()`. This performs a full re-render of the component.

#### `setState(updater)`

```typescript
protected setState(updater: () => void): void
```

Calls the `updater` function, then calls `render()`. Use this to update component state and trigger a re-render in one step.

```typescript
// Example
this.setState(() => {
  this.count += 1;
});
```

#### `query(selector)` / `queryAll(selector)`

```typescript
protected query<T extends HTMLElement>(selector: string): T
protected queryAll<T extends HTMLElement>(selector: string): T[]
```

Query elements within this component's root container. `query()` throws if no element matches. `queryAll()` returns an array (possibly empty).

#### `destroy()`

```typescript
destroy(): void
```

Clears the component's container. Call this when removing a component from the page.

### Example Component

HTML template:

```html
<template id="counter-template">
  <div class="counter">
    <span class="count">0</span>
    <button class="increment">+1</button>
  </div>
</template>
```

TypeScript:

```typescript
import { Component } from './retro/index.js';

class Counter extends Component {
  private count = 0;

  constructor(container: HTMLElement) {
    super(container, 'counter-template');
    this.render();
  }

  mount(): void {
    this.query('.count').textContent = String(this.count);
    this.query('.increment').addEventListener('click', () => {
      this.setState(() => {
        this.count += 1;
      });
    });
  }
}
```

---

### `Router`

Hash-based SPA router.

```typescript
import { Router } from './retro/index.js';
```

#### `addRoute(pattern, handler)`

```typescript
addRoute(pattern: string, handler: (params: Record<string, string>) => void): void
```

Registers a route. Patterns use `#/` prefix and support named parameters with `:`.

```typescript
router.addRoute('#/', (params) => { /* home */ });
router.addRoute('#/board/:id', (params) => {
  console.log(params.id);
});
```

#### `navigate(hash)`

```typescript
navigate(hash: string): void
```

Programmatically navigate to a hash route.

```typescript
router.navigate('#/board/42');
```

#### `start()`

```typescript
start(): void
```

Begins listening for `hashchange` events and resolves the current hash. Call this once after all routes are registered.

### Route Matching

Routes are matched by splitting on `/` and comparing segments. A route segment starting with `:` matches any path segment and captures it as a named parameter.

| Pattern | URL | Match | Params |
|---|---|---|---|
| `#/` | `#/` | Yes | `{}` |
| `#/board/:id` | `#/board/42` | Yes | `{ id: "42" }` |
| `#/board/:id` | `#/board` | No |  |

---

## Component Lifecycle

1. **Constructor**  subclass calls `super(container, templateId)`, sets up its own fields, then calls `this.render()`
2. **render()**  clears container, clones template into container, calls `mount()`
3. **mount()**  subclass binds data and events to the freshly cloned DOM
4. **setState()**  updates state, then repeats steps 23
5. **destroy()**  clears the container

Re-rendering is a full replacement: the entire component subtree is discarded and rebuilt from the template. This keeps the model simple and predictable at the cost of losing transient DOM state (scroll position, focus, input values) on each render. For most components this is acceptable; for forms and modals, render only when the dialog opens, not on every keystroke.

## Project Setup

### tsconfig.json

```json
{
  "compilerOptions": {
    "target": "ESNext",
    "module": "ESNext",
    "moduleResolution": "bundler",
    "outDir": "dist",
    "rootDir": "src",
    "strict": true,
    "esModuleInterop": true,
    "declaration": true
  },
  "include": ["src"]
}
```

### Import Paths

Since the browser loads the compiled `.js` files directly (no bundler), all import paths must use the `.js` extension:

```typescript
import { Component } from '../retro/index.js';
import { Store } from './store.js';
```

### HTML Setup

Templates and the module entry point are declared in your HTML file:

```html
<template id="my-template">
  <div class="my-component">...</div>
</template>

<script type="module" src="../dist/app/main.js"></script>
```

The user wants to decouple retro from the app. They want retro to be loaded separately, not imported via relative paths from the app code.


The approach would be:


    

  1. Load retro as a separate module that exposes itself globally or via an import map
    2. 

  2. Use an import map in index.html so app code can import { Component, Router } from 'retro' instead of '../retro/index.js'
    3. 



Import maps are the web-standard way to do this. We'd add an import map in index.html that maps 'retro' to the retro dist path, and change the app imports to use bare 'retro' specifier.


I need to set up separate TypeScript configurations for retro and the app, then update the imports to use the bare specifier. The project structure would have retro as its own directory with its own build configuration, and the app would reference it through the import map rather than relative paths.

# Decouple retro framework from app via import maps

## Context
App files (`src/app/*.ts`) currently import retro via relative path (`../retro/index.js`). This couples them and prevents building retro separately. We'll use browser-native import maps so app code imports from the bare specifier `'retro'`, and split the build into two independent tsconfigs.

## Changes

### 1. Split into two tsconfig files

**`src/retro/tsconfig.json`**  builds retro framework only
- `rootDir: .`, `outDir: ../../dist/retro`
- `include: ["."]`
- Inherits shared settings from a root `tsconfig.base.json`

**`src/app/tsconfig.json`**  builds app only
- `rootDir: .`, `outDir: ../../dist/app`
- `include: ["."]`
- `paths: { "retro": ["../retro/index.ts"] }`  tells TypeScript to resolve the bare `'retro'` specifier to the framework source for type checking

**`tsconfig.base.json`** (root)  shared compiler options
- Replaces the current `tsconfig.json`
- Contains: `target`, `module`, `moduleResolution`, `strict`, `esModuleInterop`, `declaration`, `sourceMap`
- No `include`, `outDir`, or `rootDir` (those are per-project)

### 2. Update app imports to use bare `'retro'` specifier

Files to change:
- `src/app/main.ts`: `import { Router } from 'retro'`
- `src/app/board.ts`: `import { Component } from 'retro'`
- `src/app/card-editor.ts`: `import { Component } from 'retro'`

### 3. Add import map to `public/index.html`

```html
<script type="importmap">
{
  "imports": {
    "retro": "../dist/retro/index.js"
  }
}
</script>
```

This tells the browser how to resolve `import ... from 'retro'` at runtime.

### 4. Update `package.json` build scripts

```json
"build": "npm run build:retro && npm run build:app",
"build:retro": "tsc -p src/retro/tsconfig.json",
"build:app": "tsc -p src/app/tsconfig.json"
```

### 5. Delete old `tsconfig.json`

Replaced by `tsconfig.base.json` + two project-level tsconfigs.

## Files modified
- `tsconfig.json`  renamed to `tsconfig.base.json`
- `src/retro/tsconfig.json` (new)
- `src/app/tsconfig.json` (new)
- `src/app/main.ts` (import change)
- `src/app/board.ts` (import change)
- `src/app/card-editor.ts` (import change)
- `public/index.html` (add import map)
- `package.json` (build scripts)

## Verification
1. `npm run build`  both sub-builds compile with no errors
2. `dist/retro/` and `dist/app/` contain expected `.js` + `.js.map` files
3. Open in browser  app loads and works as before

# Retro Framework + Kanban Demo Plan

## Context

Create "retro"  a minimal client-side SPA framework that embraces web standards: HTML `<template>`, native DOM API, ES modules, and TypeScript. No bundler, no virtual DOM, no SSR. Then demonstrate it with a Kanban board app using localStorage.

## Project Structure

```
retro/
 public/
    index.html          # Static HTML with <template> elements, loads ES module entry
 src/
    retro/
       component.ts    # Base Component class
       router.ts       # Hash-based SPA router
       index.ts        # Re-exports framework API
    app/
        main.ts          # App entry point, registers routes/components
        store.ts         # Kanban data model + localStorage persistence
        board.ts         # Board component (columns + cards)
        card-editor.ts   # Card create/edit dialog component
 tsconfig.json
 package.json             # (exists already)
```

## Build & Serve

- **tsconfig.json**: `target: ES2022`, `module: ES2022`, `outDir: dist`, `rootDir: src`, `strict: true`
- **Build script**: `"build": "tsc"` in package.json
- **Output**: `tsc` compiles `src/**/*.ts`  `dist/**/*.js`
- **index.html** loads `<script type="module" src="dist/app/main.js">`
- **Serve**: any static file server (e.g., `npx http-server .` or `python3 -m http.server`)

## Framework Design

### 1. `src/retro/component.ts`  Base Component Class

```typescript
abstract class Component {
  protected root: HTMLElement;

  constructor(container: HTMLElement, templateId: string) {
    // Clone <template id="templateId"> and append to container
  }

  // Subclasses override to bind events after template is cloned
  abstract mount(): void;

  // Triggers a re-render: clears container, re-clones template, re-mounts
  protected setState(updater: () => void): void {
    updater();
    this.render();
  }

  // Clears root, clones template, calls mount()
  protected render(): void { ... }

  // Helper: query within this component's root
  protected query<T extends HTMLElement>(selector: string): T { ... }
  protected queryAll<T extends HTMLElement>(selector: string): T[] { ... }

  // Cleanup hook
  destroy(): void { ... }
}
```

**Key behavior:**
- Templates are `<template>` elements defined in `index.html` with unique `id` attributes
- `render()` clones the template, appends it to the container, then calls `mount()`
- `mount()` is where subclasses query DOM nodes, set text content, add event listeners
- `setState()` calls the updater function, then re-renders (full component re-render  simple and predictable)
- Components manage a root element; re-render replaces its children

### 2. `src/retro/router.ts`  Hash Router

```typescript
class Router {
  private routes: Map<string, (params: Record<string, string>) => void>;

  addRoute(pattern: string, handler: (params) => void): void;
  navigate(hash: string): void;
  start(): void;  // Listen to hashchange, trigger initial route
}
```

- Pattern matching: simple string routes like `#/` and `#/board/:id`
- On route match, handler is called  typically mounts a component into a container element

### 3. `src/retro/index.ts`  Public API

Re-exports `Component` and `Router`.

## Kanban Demo App

### Data Model (`src/app/store.ts`)

```typescript
interface Card {
  id: string;
  title: string;
  description: string;
  columnId: string;
}

interface Column {
  id: string;
  title: string;
}

interface BoardState {
  columns: Column[];
  cards: Card[];
}

class Store {
  private state: BoardState;

  constructor()           // Load from localStorage or use defaults
  save(): void            // Persist to localStorage
  getColumns(): Column[]
  getCards(columnId: string): Card[]
  addCard(columnId: string, title: string, description: string): Card
  updateCard(id: string, updates: Partial<Card>): void
  deleteCard(id: string): void
  moveCard(cardId: string, targetColumnId: string): void
}
```

Default columns: "To Do", "In Progress", "Done".

### Board Component (`src/app/board.ts`)

- Uses template `#board-template` for overall layout
- Dynamically creates column elements, each containing its cards
- Each card is cloned from `#card-template`
- **Drag & drop**: HTML5 DnD API
  - Cards have `draggable="true"`, `dragstart` sets card ID in dataTransfer
  - Columns listen for `dragover` (prevent default) and `drop` (move card via store)
- Buttons to add new cards per column, delete cards

### Card Editor (`src/app/card-editor.ts`)

- Uses template `#card-editor-template`  a modal/dialog form
- Fields: title (input), description (textarea)
- Used for both creating and editing cards
- On submit: calls store.addCard() or store.updateCard(), then re-renders board

### Entry Point (`src/app/main.ts`)

```typescript
const store = new Store();
const router = new Router();
const appRoot = document.getElementById('app')!;

router.addRoute('#/', () => {
  new BoardComponent(appRoot, store);
});

router.start();
```

### Templates in `public/index.html`

```html
<!-- Board layout with columns container -->
<template id="board-template">...</template>

<!-- Single column with title and card list -->
<template id="column-template">...</template>

<!-- Single card with title, description, drag handle -->
<template id="card-template">...</template>

<!-- Modal form for card creation/editing -->
<template id="card-editor-template">...</template>
```

The HTML file also includes basic CSS (inline `<style>` or linked CSS file) for the Kanban layout: flexbox columns, card styling, drag-over visual feedback.

## Implementation Order

1. **tsconfig.json**  configure TypeScript compilation
2. **src/retro/component.ts**  base Component class with template cloning, setState, render
3. **src/retro/router.ts**  hash-based router
4. **src/retro/index.ts**  re-exports
5. **src/app/store.ts**  data model + localStorage
6. **src/app/board.ts**  board + column + card rendering with DnD
7. **src/app/card-editor.ts**  card create/edit dialog
8. **src/app/main.ts**  entry point, wiring
9. **public/index.html**  templates, styles, script tag
10. **Update package.json**  add build script
11. **Build & test**  `npm run build`, serve, verify in browser

## Verification

1. Run `npm run build`  should compile with no errors
2. Serve with `npx http-server . -p 8080` (or similar)
3. Open browser to `http://localhost:8080/public/index.html`
4. Verify: 3 columns displayed, can add cards, can edit/delete cards
5. Verify: drag cards between columns, drop updates column assignment
6. Verify: refresh page  cards persist via localStorage
7. Verify: clear localStorage  returns to empty default state

# Decouple retro framework from app via import maps

## Context
App files (`src/app/*.ts`) currently import retro via relative path (`../retro/index.js`). This couples them and prevents building retro separately. We'll use browser-native import maps so app code imports from the bare specifier `'retro'`, and split the build into two independent tsconfigs.

## Changes

### 1. Create `tsconfig.base.json` (shared compiler options)
Replace current `tsconfig.json` with a base config containing shared options:
- `target`, `module`, `moduleResolution`, `strict`, `esModuleInterop`, `declaration`, `sourceMap`
- No `include`, `outDir`, or `rootDir`

### 2. Create `src/retro/tsconfig.json`
- Extends `../../tsconfig.base.json`
- `rootDir: .`, `outDir: ../../dist/retro`, `include: ["."]`

### 3. Create `src/app/tsconfig.json`
- Extends `../../tsconfig.base.json`
- `rootDir: .`, `outDir: ../../dist/app`, `include: ["."]`
- `paths: { "retro": ["../retro/index.ts"] }`  resolves bare `'retro'` for type checking

### 4. Update app imports to bare `'retro'` specifier
- `src/app/main.ts`: `'../retro/index.js'`  `'retro'`
- `src/app/board.ts`: `'../retro/index.js'`  `'retro'`
- `src/app/card-editor.ts`: `'../retro/index.js'`  `'retro'`

### 5. Add import map to `public/index.html`
```html
<script type="importmap">
{
  "imports": {
    "retro": "../dist/retro/index.js"
  }
}
</script>
```
This tells the browser how to resolve `import ... from 'retro'` at runtime.

### 6. Update `package.json` build scripts
```json
"build": "npm run build:retro && npm run build:app",
"build:retro": "tsc -p src/retro/tsconfig.json",
"build:app": "tsc -p src/app/tsconfig.json"
```

### 7. Delete old `tsconfig.json`

## Files modified
- `tsconfig.json`  renamed to `tsconfig.base.json` (shared options only)
- `src/retro/tsconfig.json` (new)
- `src/app/tsconfig.json` (new)
- `src/app/main.ts` (import path)
- `src/app/board.ts` (import path)
- `src/app/card-editor.ts` (import path)
- `public/index.html` (add import map)
- `package.json` (build scripts)

## Verification
1. `npm run build`  both sub-builds compile with no errors
2. `dist/retro/` and `dist/app/` contain `.js` + `.js.map` files
3. Open in browser  app loads and works as before

import { Router } from '../retro/index.js';

import { Component } from '../retro/index.js';
import { Store } from './store.js';
import { CardEditor } from './card-editor.js';

export class BoardComponent extends Component {
  private store: Store;
  private editorContainer: HTMLElement | null = null;

  constructor(container: HTMLElement, store: Store) {
    super(container, 'board-template');
    this.store = store;
    this.render();
  }

  mount(): void {
    const columnsContainer = this.query<HTMLElement>('.board-columns');

    for (const column of this.store.getColumns()) {
      const colTemplate = document.getElementById('column-template') as HTMLTemplateElement;
      const colClone = colTemplate.content.cloneNode(true) as DocumentFragment;
      const colEl = colClone.firstElementChild as HTMLElement;

      colEl.querySelector('.column-title')!.textContent = column.title;
      colEl.dataset.columnId = column.id;

      // Drag and drop on column
      colEl.addEventListener('dragover', (e) => {
        e.preventDefault();
        colEl.classList.add('drag-over');
      });

      colEl.addEventListener('dragleave', () => {
        colEl.classList.remove('drag-over');
      });

      colEl.addEventListener('drop', (e) => {
        e.preventDefault();
        colEl.classList.remove('drag-over');
        const cardId = e.dataTransfer?.getData('text/plain');
        if (cardId) {
          this.store.moveCard(cardId, column.id);
          this.render();
        }
      });

      // Render cards in this column
      const cardList = colEl.querySelector('.card-list') as HTMLElement;
      const cards = this.store.getCards(column.id);

      for (const card of cards) {
        const cardTemplate = document.getElementById('card-template') as HTMLTemplateElement;
        const cardClone = cardTemplate.content.cloneNode(true) as DocumentFragment;
        const cardEl = cardClone.firstElementChild as HTMLElement;

        cardEl.querySelector('.card-title')!.textContent = card.title;
        const descEl = cardEl.querySelector('.card-description') as HTMLElement;
        if (descEl) {
          descEl.textContent = card.description;
        }
        cardEl.dataset.cardId = card.id;
        cardEl.setAttribute('draggable', 'true');

        cardEl.addEventListener('dragstart', (e) => {
          e.dataTransfer?.setData('text/plain', card.id);
        });

        // Edit button
        const editBtn = cardEl.querySelector('.card-edit-btn') as HTMLButtonElement;
        editBtn.addEventListener('click', () => {
          this.openEditor(column.id, card.id);
        });

        // Delete button
        const deleteBtn = cardEl.querySelector('.card-delete-btn') as HTMLButtonElement;
        deleteBtn.addEventListener('click', () => {
          this.store.deleteCard(card.id);
          this.render();
        });

        cardList.appendChild(cardEl);
      }

      // Add card button
      const addBtn = colEl.querySelector('.column-add-btn') as HTMLButtonElement;
      addBtn.addEventListener('click', () => {
        this.openEditor(column.id, null);
      });

      columnsContainer.appendChild(colEl);
    }
  }

  private openEditor(columnId: string, cardId: string | null): void {
    // Create a container for the editor overlay
    this.editorContainer = document.createElement('div');
    document.body.appendChild(this.editorContainer);

    new CardEditor(this.editorContainer, this.store, columnId, cardId, () => {
      this.closeEditor();
      this.render();
    });
  }

  private closeEditor(): void {
    if (this.editorContainer) {
      this.editorContainer.remove();
      this.editorContainer = null;
    }
  }
}

import { Component } from '../retro/index.js';
import { Store } from './store.js';

export class CardEditor extends Component {
  private onClose: () => void;

import { Component } from '../retro/index.js';
import { Store } from './store.js';

export class CardEditor extends Component {
  private onClose: () => void;
  private store: Store;
  private editingCardId: string | null;
  private columnId: string;

  constructor(
    container: HTMLElement,
    store: Store,
    columnId: string,
    editingCardId: string | null,
    onClose: () => void
  ) {
    super(container, 'card-editor-template');
    this.store = store;
    this.columnId = columnId;
    this.editingCardId = editingCardId;
    this.onClose = onClose;
    this.render();
  }

  mount(): void {
    const form = this.query<HTMLFormElement>('.card-editor-form');
    const titleInput = this.query<HTMLInputElement>('.card-title-input');
    const descInput = this.query<HTMLTextAreaElement>('.card-desc-input');
    const heading = this.query<HTMLElement>('.card-editor-heading');
    const cancelBtn = this.query<HTMLButtonElement>('.card-editor-cancel');

    if (this.editingCardId) {
      const card = this.store.getCard(this.editingCardId);
      if (card) {
        titleInput.value = card.title;
        descInput.value = card.description;
        heading.textContent = 'Edit Card';
      }
    } else {
      heading.textContent = 'New Card';
    }

    form.addEventListener('submit', (e) => {
      e.preventDefault();
      const title = titleInput.value.trim();
      if (!title) return;
      const description = descInput.value.trim();

      if (this.editingCardId) {
        this.store.updateCard(this.editingCardId, { title, description });
      } else {
        this.store.addCard(this.columnId, title, description);
      }
      this.onClose();
    });

    cancelBtn.addEventListener('click', () => {
      this.onClose();
    });

    const overlay = this.query<HTMLElement>('.card-editor-overlay');
    overlay.addEventListener('click', (e) => {
      if (e.target === overlay) {
        this.onClose();
      }
    });
  }
}

The issue is that paths causes TypeScript to resolve retro to ../retro/index.ts, which pulls that file into the compilation. Since rootDir is set to . (src/app), files outside it cause an error.


Options:


    

  1. Remove rootDir and set rootDir to ../ (src)  but then output structure mirrors src/ with app/ and retro/ subdirs
    

    2. 

  2. Use baseUrl + paths but also set rootDir to ..  same issue with output structure
    

    3. 

  3. Use TypeScript project references with composite
    

    4. 

  4. Don't use paths at all  instead create a retro.d.ts ambient module declaration
    

    5. 

  5. Create an ambient module declaration in src/app/retro.d.ts that re-exports from the retro source, keeping the output flat
    

    6. 



The ambient module approach seems cleanest since it avoids the output structure problem entirely.

export abstract class Component {
  protected root: HTMLElement;
  private templateId: string;

  constructor(container: HTMLElement, templateId: string) {
    this.root = container;
    this.templateId = templateId;
  }

  abstract mount(): void;

  protected setState(updater: () => void): void {
    updater();
    this.render();
  }

  protected render(): void {
    this.root.innerHTML = '';
    const template = document.getElementById(this.templateId) as HTMLTemplateElement | null;
    if (!template) {
      throw new Error(`Template #${this.templateId} not found`);
    }
    const clone = template.content.cloneNode(true) as DocumentFragment;
    this.root.appendChild(clone);
    this.mount();
  }

  protected query<T extends HTMLElement>(selector: string): T {
    const el = this.root.querySelector<T>(selector);
    if (!el) {
      throw new Error(`Element not found: ${selector}`);
    }
    return el;
  }

  protected queryAll<T extends HTMLElement>(selector: string): T[] {
    return Array.from(this.root.querySelectorAll<T>(selector));
  }

  destroy(): void {
    this.root.innerHTML = '';
  }
}

type RouteHandler = (params: Record<string, string>) => void;

interface Route {
  pattern: string;
  parts: string[];
  handler: RouteHandler;
}

export class Router {
  private routes: Route[] = [];

  addRoute(pattern: string, handler: RouteHandler): void {
    const parts = pattern.replace(/^#/, '').split('/');
    this.routes.push({ pattern, parts, handler });
  }

  navigate(hash: string): void {
    window.location.hash = hash;
  }

  start(): void {
    window.addEventListener('hashchange', () => this.resolve());
    this.resolve();
  }

  private resolve(): void {
    const hash = window.location.hash || '#/';
    const path = hash.replace(/^#/, '');
    const segments = path.split('/');

    for (const route of this.routes) {
      const params = this.match(route.parts, segments);
      if (params !== null) {
        route.handler(params);
        return;
      }
    }
  }

  private match(
    routeParts: string[],
    pathParts: string[]
  ): Record<string, string> | null {
    if (routeParts.length !== pathParts.length) return null;

    const params: Record<string, string> = {};
    for (let i = 0; i < routeParts.length; i++) {
      if (routeParts[i].startsWith(':')) {
        params[routeParts[i].slice(1)] = pathParts[i];
      } else if (routeParts[i] !== pathParts[i]) {
        return null;
      }
    }
    return params;
  }
}

The user wants a GitHub Pages deployment workflow. The app serves from public/ with built JS in dist/. For GitHub Pages, I need to combine public/ and dist/ into a single deployable artifact. Let me think about what's needed:


    

  1. The public/index.html references ../dist/retro/index.js and ../dist/app/main.js - these relative paths assume public/ and dist/ are siblings. For GitHub Pages, I'll need to adjust the structure so everything is under one directory, or adjust the paths.
    2. 



Actually, let me re-read the index.html to understand the path structure.


The index.html has:


    

  • style.css referenced relative to public/
    • 

  • ../dist/retro/index.js and ../dist/app/main.js going up from public/ to find dist/
    • 



For GitHub Pages, I need to decide between copying everything into a single directory with adjusted paths, or deploying from the repo root where the relative paths would still work but the site would be served from /public/ instead of the root.


The cleanest solution is to set up a build step that creates a _site directory with index.html at the root alongside dist/, then update the paths in the HTML to reference dist/ directly instead of going up a level. This way I can use GitHub Actions to deploy the built site cleanly. I think the cleanest approach is to copy the public files to the site root, place dist alongside it, and use sed during the deploy step to rewrite the ../dist/ import paths to ./dist/ in the HTML file.

# Deploy Kanban demo to GitHub Pages

## Context
The app is served from `public/` with built JS in `dist/`. For GitHub Pages at `godmar.github.io/retro`, we need both under one root. The `index.html` references `../dist/` (sibling relationship), which needs to become `./dist/` when everything is flattened.

## Plan

### Create `.github/workflows/deploy.yml`
A workflow that:
1. Triggers on push to `master`
2. Installs deps, runs `npm run build`
3. Assembles `_site/` directory:
   - Copy `public/*`  `_site/`
   - Copy `dist/`  `_site/dist/`
   - `sed` to fix `../dist/`  `./dist/` in `_site/index.html`
4. Uses `actions/upload-pages-artifact` + `actions/deploy-pages` to publish

### Enable Pages in repo settings
The workflow uses the "GitHub Actions" pages source (not branch-based), so no `gh-pages` branch is needed.

## Files
- `.github/workflows/deploy.yml` (new)

## Verification
- Push to master triggers the workflow
- `godmar.github.io/retro` loads the Kanban app

# Decouple retro framework from app via import maps

## Context
App files (`src/app/*.ts`) currently import retro via relative path (`../retro/index.js`). This couples them and prevents building retro separately. We'll use browser-native import maps so app code imports from the bare specifier `'retro'`, and split the build into two independent tsconfigs.

## Changes

### 1. Create `tsconfig.base.json` (shared compiler options)
Replace current `tsconfig.json` with a base config containing shared options:
- `target`, `module`, `moduleResolution`, `strict`, `esModuleInterop`, `declaration`, `sourceMap`
- No `include`, `outDir`, or `rootDir`

### 2. Create `src/retro/tsconfig.json`
- Extends `../../tsconfig.base.json`
- `rootDir: .`, `outDir: ../../dist/retro`, `include: ["."]`

### 3. Create `src/app/tsconfig.json`
- Extends `../../tsconfig.base.json`
- `rootDir: .`, `outDir: ../../dist/app`, `include: ["."]`
- `paths: { "retro": ["../retro/index.ts"] }`  resolves bare `'retro'` for type checking

### 4. Update app imports to bare `'retro'` specifier
- `src/app/main.ts`: `'../retro/index.js'`  `'retro'`
- `src/app/board.ts`: `'../retro/index.js'`  `'retro'`
- `src/app/card-editor.ts`: `'../retro/index.js'`  `'retro'`

### 5. Add import map to `public/index.html`
```html
<script type="importmap">
{
  "imports": {
    "retro": "../dist/retro/index.js"
  }
}
</script>
```
This tells the browser how to resolve `import ... from 'retro'` at runtime.

### 6. Update `package.json` build scripts
```json
"build": "npm run build:retro && npm run build:app",
"build:retro": "tsc -p src/retro/tsconfig.json",
"build:app": "tsc -p src/app/tsconfig.json"
```

### 7. Delete old `tsconfig.json`

## Files modified
- `tsconfig.json`  renamed to `tsconfig.base.json` (shared options only)
- `src/retro/tsconfig.json` (new)
- `src/app/tsconfig.json` (new)
- `src/app/main.ts` (import path)
- `src/app/board.ts` (import path)
- `src/app/card-editor.ts` (import path)
- `public/index.html` (add import map)
- `package.json` (build scripts)

## Verification
1. `npm run build`  both sub-builds compile with no errors
2. `dist/retro/` and `dist/app/` contain `.js` + `.js.map` files
3. Open in browser  app loads and works as before

You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer questions about the code behavior.

# Deploy Kanban demo to GitHub Pages

## Context
The app is served from `public/` with built JS in `dist/`. For GitHub Pages at `godmar.github.io/retro`, we need both under one root. The `index.html` references `../dist/` (sibling relationship), which needs to become `./dist/` when everything is flattened into a single site directory.

## Plan

### Create `.github/workflows/deploy.yml`
A single workflow file that:
1. Triggers on push to `master`
2. Sets up Node, installs deps, runs `npm run build`
3. Assembles `_site/` directory:
   - Copy `public/*`  `_site/`
   - Copy `dist/`  `_site/dist/`
   - Fix `../dist/`  `./dist/` in `_site/index.html` (two occurrences: import map and script src)
4. Uses `actions/upload-pages-artifact` + `actions/deploy-pages` to publish

Uses the "GitHub Actions" pages source (not branch-based), so no `gh-pages` branch is needed.

## Files
- `.github/workflows/deploy.yml` (new)

## Verification
- Push to master triggers the workflow
- `godmar.github.io/retro` loads the Kanban app

name: Deploy to GitHub Pages

on:
  push:
    branches: [master]

permissions:
  pages: write
  id-token: write

concurrency:
  group: pages
  cancel-in-progress: true

jobs:
  build-and-deploy:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    environment:
      name: github-pages
      url: ${{ steps.deployment.outputs.page_url }}
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4

      - uses: actions/setup-node@v4
        with:
          node-version: 20

      - run: npm ci

      - run: npm run build

      - name: Assemble site
        run: |
          mkdir _site
          cp -r public/* _site/
          cp -r dist/ _site/dist/
          sed -i 's|\.\./dist/|./dist/|g' _site/index.html

      - uses: actions/upload-pages-artifact@v3

      - name: Deploy to GitHub Pages
        id: deployment
        uses: actions/deploy-pages@v4

name: Deploy to GitHub Pages

on:
  push:
    branches: [master]

permissions:
  pages: write
  id-token: write

concurrency:
  group: pages
  cancel-in-progress: true

jobs:
  build-and-deploy:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    environment:
      name: github-pages
      url: ${{ steps.deployment.outputs.page_url }}
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4

      - uses: actions/setup-node@v4
        with:
          node-version: 20

      - run: npm ci

      - run: npm run build

      - name: Assemble site
        run: |
          mkdir _site
          cp -r public/* _site/
          cp -r dist/ _site/dist/
          sed -i 's|\.\./dist/|./dist/|g' _site/index.html

      - uses: actions/upload-pages-artifact@v3

      - name: Deploy to GitHub Pages
        id: deployment
        uses: actions/deploy-pages@v4

But you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer questions about the code behavior.

# retro Framework Documentation

retro is a minimal client-side SPA framework built on web standards: HTML `<template>` elements, the native DOM API, and ES modules. It provides two core abstractions  `Component` and `Router`  and nothing else.

## Design Philosophy

# retro Framework Documentation

retro is a minimal client-side SPA framework built on web standards: HTML `<template>` elements, the native DOM API, and ES modules. It provides two core abstractions  `Component` and `Router`  and nothing else.

## Design Philosophy

- **No virtual DOM.** Components clone HTML `<template>` elements and manipulate the real DOM directly.
- **No bundler.** TypeScript compiles to ES modules that the browser loads natively.
- **No magic.** State management is explicit. Re-rendering is a full replace of the component's DOM subtree.
- **Templates in HTML.** UI structure lives in `<template>` tags in your HTML file, not in JavaScript strings or JSX.

## API Reference

### `Component`

Abstract base class for all UI components.

```typescript
import { Component } from './retro/index.js';
```

name: Deploy to GitHub Pages

on:
  push:
    branches: [master]

permissions:
  pages: write
  id-token: write

concurrency:
  group: pages
  cancel-in-progress: true

jobs:
  build-and-deploy:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    environment:
      name: github-pages
      url: ${{ steps.deployment.outputs.page_url }}
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4

      - uses: actions/setup-node@v4
        with:
          node-version: 20

      - run: npm ci

      - run: npm run build

      - name: Assemble site
        run: |
          mkdir _site
          cp -r public/* _site/
          cp -r dist/ _site/dist/
          cp -r src/ _site/src/
          sed -i 's|\.\./dist/|./dist/|g' _site/index.html

      - uses: actions/upload-pages-artifact@v3

      - name: Deploy to GitHub Pages
        id: deployment
        uses: actions/deploy-pages@v4

name: Deploy to GitHub Pages

on:
  push:
    branches: [master]

permissions:
  pages: write
  id-token: write

concurrency:
  group: pages
  cancel-in-progress: true

jobs:
  build-and-deploy:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    environment:
      name: github-pages
      url: ${{ steps.deployment.outputs.page_url }}
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4

      - uses: actions/setup-node@v4
        with:
          node-version: 20

      - run: npm ci

      - run: npm run build

      - name: Assemble site
        run: |
          mkdir _site
          cp -r public/* _site/
          cp -r dist/ _site/dist/
          cp -r src/ _site/src/
          sed -i 's|\.\./dist/|./dist/|g' _site/index.html
          pandoc docs/retro-framework.md -s --metadata title="retro Framework Documentation" -o _site/retro-framework.html

      - uses: actions/upload-pages-artifact@v3

      - name: Deploy to GitHub Pages
        id: deployment
        uses: actions/deploy-pages@v4

name: Deploy to GitHub Pages

on:
  push:
    branches: [master]

permissions:
  pages: write
  id-token: write

concurrency:
  group: pages
  cancel-in-progress: true

jobs:
  build-and-deploy:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    environment:
      name: github-pages
      url: ${{ steps.deployment.outputs.page_url }}
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4

      - uses: actions/setup-node@v4
        with:
          node-version: 20

      - run: npm ci

      - run: npm run build

      - name: Assemble site
        run: |
          mkdir _site
          cp -r public/* _site/
          cp -r dist/ _site/dist/
          cp -r src/ _site/src/

      - uses: actions/upload-pages-artifact@v3

      - name: Deploy to GitHub Pages
        id: deployment
        uses: actions/deploy-pages@v4
